*** This review may contain spoilers ***

I was very much looking forward to seeing 'The Conspirator' and even went out and purchased an audio book, 'The Assassin's Accomplice' , which I listened to before seeing the film. As a history buff, I find books about such memorable historical events as the Lincoln assassination quite fascinating. Unfortunately, due to budgetary constraints, Director Robert Redford and his creative team were unable to focus on the meat and potatoes of the story: that is, the events leading up to the actual assassination itself. Instead, Redford has offered up a quickie montage of the conspirators' machinations, with the bulk of the film concentrating on the aftermath of President Lincoln's tragic demise--specifically the trial and execution of the principal actors in the assassination plot.

What's missing in this by-the-numbers history is a sense of who the conspirators were--their personalities and the context of the times they lived in. Instead, the main protagonist is a defense attorney, Frederick Aiken, who defended Mary Surratt, a principal conspirator in the Lincoln assassination who also happened to be the first woman ever executed by the US government. Most of the film focuses on Aiken's anguish over his perception that Mary Surratt was not treated fairly by the government, especially in regards to the fact that she was tried in front of a military commission and not a civilian jury. Redford obviously wants us to draw a parallel between the events that occurred in 1865 and today's recent controversy over whether the 9/11 conspirators (and Gitmo detainees) should be classified as enemy combatants and tried before military tribunals. In Redford's analysis, the post-Civil War government (and particularly the military) are the bad guys. What Redford conveniently fails to point out, is that perhaps the greatest usurper of the Constitution at that time was Abraham Lincoln himself (as the President suspended Habeas corpus for the entire duration of the Civil War--abrogating the right of the courts to determine if the custodian of persons in detention has the lawful authority to keep said detainees behind bars).

After the montage of the events leading up to the assassination, we get a few flashbacks during the trial dramatizing what went on before and after President Lincoln's murder. It was well established during the trial that Mary Surratt met with John Wilkes Booth on numerous occasions at her boarding house in Washington, D.C., and in the hands of a professional screenwriter, that relationship could have been fleshed out. But instead, we catch only fleeting glimpses of Booth and find out virtually nothing about him. By failing to show Booth's relationship with both Mary Surratt and her son, John, one gets the wrong impression that Mary was an innocent victim in this whole affair. The fact remains that the conspirators promoted the beliefs of the Confederacy, a cause infused with racism. Is it possible that Redford sugar coats Mary Surratt and her co-conspirators so that we don't come away with the impression that they are racists? (For example, Lewis Payne, the conspirator who almost stabbed Secretary of State Seward to death on the night of Lincoln's assassination, was arrested in Baltimore a few weeks before the assassination--Payne almost beat an African-American cleaning woman to death because, in his mind, she was getting 'too uppity'-why leave something like that out?)

I have no objection to screenwriters playing fast and loose with history in order to enhance dramatic events. One such example in 'The Conspirator' is that Mary Surratt is shown during the film without the black veil which she wore at the trial, completely covering her face. Historically, Surratt only lifted the veil during the trial when called upon to identify herself before the Court. Dramatically it would not have worked in the film had her face remained covered , so I had no problem with the films' scenarists depicting Mary without her face covered. But I did have a big problem with the scene in which Mary admits to Aiken that she was aware of Booth's kidnapping plot (Booth's initial plan was to kidnap Lincoln and hold him for ransom). The fact is that Mary Surratt made no such admissions--she provided no explanations whatsoever as to her conduct before and after the assassination. Because she failed to provide any plausible explanation for her conduct and continuously denied any culpability, her attorneys were unable to mount a serious defense. By falsely suggesting that Mary Surratt admitted to an awareness of the Booth kidnapping plot, Redford can conveniently imply that she took some responsibility for her involvement with the conspirators, without having to admit any knowledge of or involvement in the actual assassination.

Perhaps it would would have been a much better film had the films' scenarists made Louis Weichmann the protagonist, not Aiken. Weichmann, a Federal employee, was friends with Mary and John Surratt and was living at the boardinghouse at the time of the assassination. After the trial, and for the rest of his life, he was forced to defend himself from both southern sympathizers who held him responsible for Mary Surratt's death due to his testimony against her at the trial and those northerners who suspected he was part of the conspiracy with John Surratt.

'The Conspirator' is not a complete lost cause. For one who wants to learn about the basics surrounding the Lincoln Assassination and the conspirator's trial, the film does a fair job in highlighting the principal events. What's more, there are some excellent performances here--especially Robin Wright as Mary, Tom Wilkinson as Reverdy Johnson (Mary's chief attorney) and Kevin Kline, who has a brief part as Lincoln's Secretary of War.

Was she or wasn't she guilty? That's a question 'The Conspirator' manages to skirt almost entirely. The evidence suggests a strong circumstantial case against Mary Surratt. Her death sentence is another issue. But for Robert Redford, Surratt is a victim of government injustice and thus her actual guilt is of little concern.

Redford's  star-studded take on Gregory Bernstein & James Solomon's story (and screenplay) surrounding the true-story of the female conspirator of the Lincoln Assassination. The mother of John Surratt, the conspirator at large, is trialled, in part to bring (john) Surratt out of hiding. An impressive job here, by Redford, in making an historical footnote Mary Surratt into an interesting if possibly noble character!  But much of the movie depends on James McAvoy's emotion portrayal of Union-vet/war-hero  and neophyte lawyer Frederick Aiken, who defended the sole female conspirator  after Wilkes Booth was shot.

The film also follows the historical strand of Kevin Kline as Secretary of War Edwin Stanton who while running the government immediately following The assassination is overly eager to have an execution(s) and be done with the whole affair. Great old-school period drama with Robin Wright,  Evan Rachel Wood, Tom Wilkinson, Justin Long, Danny Huston, Norman Reedus, Colm Meaney (great to see Colm again!).

Once again, the young actor JAMES McAVOY gives an earnest and altogether convincing portrait of a man assigned to be the defense lawyer for Mary Surratt, accused as one of the conspirators in the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

Since the whole story is told from his point of view (and Redford's), it emerges as a somewhat biased look at how events might have unfolded, but taking no firm stand on the innocence or guilt of the accused. As the nation mourns the sudden death of its leader taken from them just as the Civil War ended, we are told that justice must be swift to heal the wounds of the public and satisfy a thirst for revenge. It's that viewpoint that makes this film relevant today, in view of other controversial historical events, but first and foremost the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963.

One glaring quibble: Apparently, to fully immerse the viewer in this time of history and to suit the flavor of the grim tale, Redford has chosen to use very muted color photography so that this is almost a sepia tone experience. But do we have to be reminded so flagrantly that this was the candlelit era? Scenes outside of the courtroom could have used flashes of real color, as could the social circle interiors of other scenes instead of keeping the low-key lighting so constant. It became a distraction for me. He may as well have used glorious B&W.

Other technical aspects are fine and the background score is effective without becoming overwhelming. ROBIN WRIGHT PENN plays Mary Surratt with quiet dignity and strength. KEVIN KLINE is almost unrecognizable as the stubbornly determined EDWIN STANTON seeking quick justice, EVAN RACHEL WOOD is effective as the distraught daughter Anna Surratt, and JOHNNY SIMMONS is sobering as the accused woman's son who manages to escape imprisonment for his role in the John Wilkes Booth caper. However, his character and motives are not fleshed out at all by the script, nor is his key relationship with his mother, Mary Surratt made at all clear.

Biggest supporting role goes to TOM WILKINSON as the man who urges McAvoy to take the defense case against his wishes. He and McAvoy share most of the running time on screen and do magnificent jobs.

History buffs will no doubt find this more interesting than the average movie fan looking for a more adventurous look at the past, but it is competently made, despite some flaws, and does recreate the actual events in a satisfying manner by use of flashbacks and an intelligent script. But did it have to be so dark?

What I know of the search for the killers of President Abraham Lincoln comes primarily from the mesmerizing book, Manhunt. Mary Surratt was one of about five who were charged with conspiracy and stood trial. Never fully answering whether or not she was guilty, the film is definitely sympathetic to her. In fact, it presents her character and her religious faith in a very respectful manner. I found this film to be every bit as engaging as was Manhunt.

As a history fan and costume drama lover, I was excited when I saw the trailers for *The Conspirator.* I have to say the movie did not live up to its promise, though. It kept having moments where it could have broken through and become very gripping, but it never actually got there.

Of course *The Conspirator* is not about Mary Surratt but Guantanamo, so it shouldn't be too surprising that the Civil War aspect is given no more depth than the window dressing it is. The preachiness was annoying (although I actually agree that the government has no business suspending habeas corpus), but, from Robert Redford, I expected it.

What I did not expect, though, was that someone could take as intense and tumultuous a time as the Civil War and make it flat and uninteresting. Frankly, my mind wandered a lot of the time, except when it was noting oddities like how Frederick Aiken was portrayed as a single man with a girlfriend, when in fact he was married at that time.

In the end, I just found *The Conspirator* unconvincing, unengaging, and disappointing. It felt like the kind of movie we used to have to watch in History class--only at least back then I wouldn't have had to cough up $11 to see it. I would say if you want to see it, wait till it comes out on DVD.

Most American's are familiar with the Civil War and its aftermath, but one of the lesser known aspects of the Civil War is the rounding up of conspirators in the assassination of Abraham Lincoln and their subsequent trial, in particular the case of Mary Surratt. This is the story Robert Redford brings us in "The Conspirator."

The story in "The Conspirator" isn't one we're all unfamiliar with. A young inexperienced lawyer, Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy) is assigned a client he initially thinks is guilty, Mary Suratt (Robin Wright) in a conspiracy to assassinate Abraham Lincoln. As facts come to light and the prosecution obviously takes liberties in trying to hide evidence, pressure witnesses, and allow for only one viewpoint of evidence, that he slowly comes to the realization that while his client maybe guilty she isn't getting a fair trial and provides a more vigorous defense then at first thought possible. John Grisham has told this story many times.

The movie is told from Aiken's point of view in his defense of Suratt, how it affects his life and relationships, and as his defense becomes more effective how he's exiled from Washington society and he starts to become suspect by his friends and the very people that appointed him to the position. In brief flashbacks we're also shown just enough of the conspiracy and the action of the conspirators that we can know what's going on.

This isn't a glamor role for Robin Wright she barely wears make up, her lips dry and parched after being in prison for a month. She plays Suratt with matronly dignity expected of a woman of the age. James McAvoy gives a strong performance as a Union Captain who comes back from war and wants to return to his private life only to be thrust back into fighting, only this time in the courtroom. Kevin Kline's Edwin Stanton is absolutely ruthless in his pursuit of the assassins of Abraham Lincoln, and we're shown that ruthlessness almost immediately when he bars the distraught Mary Todd Lincoln from the President's side after he's taken from Ford's theater. In the supporting cast Evan Rachael Wood as Anna Surrat stands out, and Stephen Root, while having a small role always makes it interesting.

Director Robert Redford shot this film beautifully, the gaslights glisten, and a couple of times looks like a Georges Seurat painting, perhaps in contrast to the cramped and war torn buildings most of the action occurs in and around.

Yes, Redford's story has resonances and similarities to today's world, but history always will be relevant to the day, and the adage that "those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it" was never truer. "The Conspirator" reminds us of that history. But we aren't beaten over the head with a "message," Redford gives voice to both sides of the argument, with Stanton arguing that all measures should be taken to roundup the conspirators and put in front of a military tribunal in the name of expediency in healing a nation torn apart. Aiken voices the other side of the argument, of why do we fight wars in the name of freedom and liberty if we're just to put them to the side? Although, Redford leans to the side of when the world changes the constitution shouldn't.

I've read a bit about the Civil War, and thought Mary Suratt, while railroaded by Stanton, had known what her son and Booth were up to. Now, I'm not so sure.

This film's target audience is leagues beyond just the Civil War fan. "The Conspirator" draws the viewer into a period of time and forces a decision between emotions likely felt by North & South Americans of the era. Robert Redford (director/producer) takes a side-note of Lincoln and Civil War history and catapults it into a very believable, re-living, docu-drama-like, story that will touch you at a human and political level. Some viewers will despise the end, others cheer, but oddly, both sides will consider it justice. But was it?

Looking at historical accounts, one can find the story buried in the lesser known details of the War's end and a Presidential assassination. Mary Surratt (Robin Wright-`Forrest Gump') is arrested with other men and accused of a murder conspiracy. A planned attack on 3 political leaders. One, Lincoln, would die, and one woman, Mary, would be pushed toward justice at a vengeance speed. No trial by peers, but a tribunal justice, with the deck stacked hugely against innocence. Even her lawyer, Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy-`Atonement' `Narnia') ex-Union fighter was chosen to hasten a guilty verdict and quick hanging. He is reluctant to defend and believes her guilty. The attorney role causes romantic troubles for Aiken, but that is a minor bit of the story. The relationship between Aiken and his client, as well as political/military figures including commission head Gen. Hunter (Colm Meeney) and War Secretary Stanton (Kevin Kline) is the basis for the masterfully written story.

This should win awards, perhaps not as individual acting moments, but overall, and on the top of the deserving list is screenplay writer James Solomon. The writing IS the story. A documentary written in dramatic dialogue. The director has brought the written masterpiece alive. The visual effects are a constant 1860s view as through tintype photographs or panoramic daguerreotypes of the era but with subtle color. That is just another stellar decision that gives this film such period authenticity and charm. It reminded me of a stage show once attended of "Scrooge" with the entire theater in a light London-like fog. Both were historically invigorating to the senses. "The Conspirator" is a towering achievement and quite appropriate in the opening days of the Civil War's Sesquicentennial. Let's hope this spurs more films related to this era, and proves that all do NOT need to be feature-length battle scenes. This is a very fast and emotional two hours of viewing.

Painstaking detail to costuming and sets are also to be regarded. In the scene of the hanging (not all tried were lynched) there is obvious consideration to actual photographs taken in 1865. This is a dramatic portrayal, but will also be considered by some to be as close to a documentary as one can get with this historic material. Top hat's off to director Redford and writer Solomon.

I was so excited about reading the preliminary accounts of this movie that I attended the second showing on opening day. It was worth the theater price, and I WILL be buying the DVD when available. See it. It's brings back Kennedy assassination memories, and yet hits true to today's politics as well. Dare I add this is educational? PG-13 and students SHOULD see this for U.S. history and civics content.

Like his fellow film icon Kevin Costner, Robert Redford is a true son of the Sixties and for the past twenty years has been trying to out-costner Kevin in sentimental stories of underdog struggles. Both the icons lean towards pop history, and Redford's latest in this category is "The Conspirator", the tale of Mary Surratt, the widow who was accused of harboring in her Washington DC boarding house the men who plotted the assassination of Abraham Lincoln in 1865. Redford has tried to give this telling a great deal of importance, but perhaps it was his very gravity which betrayed him. In other words, a great deal of the picture is dull. Much of the conflict is performed in daytime drama style, draining the picture of its more successful elements; and, unfortunately, the whole production has a somewhat facile pre-fab appearance. The 19th Century has rarely looked so neat. The only thing missing is the candy-box Technicolor from M~G~M's version of "Little Women". I recall only one shot in "The Conspirator" of someone smoking, and the Capital's streets seem spotless. Then for some unknown reason (perhaps to balance all the PC primness) there's a completely unbelievable scene in which a young beau jocosely moons a mixed company at an elegant soire. In 1865? I don't think so. Maybe Redford got the 1860s confused with the 1960s. He also seems a little confused about his characters' viewpoints: the young Yankee lawyer who is chosen to defend Mrs Surratt at first seems repelled by her, then somewhat abruptly admires her, perhaps won over by her quiet dignity. Actually, Mrs Surratt seems quiet to the point of indifference, particularly for someone on trial for her life. Then there's her implicated son whom the screenplay tries desperately to make sympathetic, but the fact is he stands by and lets his mother be executed, stating in one of the final scenes that he didn't really think they'd do it. But obviously it's the young lawyer who is meant to be the story's hero. The movie opens with a scene on an 1863 battlefield in which the wounded officer insists that his comrade be tended to first ("That's an order!"); and it ends with his leaving his corrupt profession and entering the pure world of journalism. Yes, the Washington Post, which exposed Watergate and brought the aggressive idealism of the Sixties to its climax. All this hero needs are love beads and a copy of Charles A Reich.

Not long ago, I discovered that The Conspirator was available on Amazon Instant Video. Huzzah, I thought. I had the house to myself and I figured it was the perfect time to enjoy a Civil War era film. I made it through twenty minutes and turned it off.

Keep in mind, I have never walked out on or turned off any Civil War film. Ever. And I have sat through Gods and Generals TWICE. Clearly I am committed to Hollywood's take on this epic historical event. But I just could not stomach this wretched piece of rubbish.

If the first twenty minutes were any indication of things to come in the rest of the film, then I suppose I would have been treated to more over-wrought testaments to "American" jurisprudence - the right to a trial by one's peers and the notion of innocence before guilt can be established without any element of doubt. Thanks for the elementary lesson in  law.

But wait, there are more lessons to be learned here. Yes - Mary Surratt was indeed a woman. Her implication in the murder of Abraham Lincoln and her subsequent execution were shocking to be sure. Thanks for the elementary lesson in nineteenth-century gender assumptions.

The problem, at least in the first few scenes that I could watch, is that both of these issues are of great significance - then and now - but they were glossed over in a tisk-tisk fashion only after dripping a taste of sickening "look-at-how-we've-progressed-but-there's-still-work-to-be-done" syrup on for good measure. And even this was done so in a mumbly dead-pan stumble fest. Such nonsense can only refelct some of the worst writing, the worst acting, the worst directing, or a combination of the three. I would have been more riveted watching a plate of white toast get stale as time slowly, painfully passed.

Not that the film was completely lacking in merits. I got a bit of a chuckle at the actor who played John Wilkes Booth. With all the southern-Gothic charm of a junior high production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, his brutish pronunciation of the Virginia state motto in the Ford's Theatre scene - sic semper tyrannis - was delightful. I suppose this was merely an effort to "southernize" or if you like, "Rebelize" the president's assassin (who was not a redneck but a classically trained actor), by giving him a slightly raspier Jethro Bodine-esque accent. Such clumsy and obvious efforts make me laugh.

But who knows? Maybe the utter brilliance of rest of the film made up for the first twenty minutes. I will never know. Perhaps it got slightly less patronizingly preachy. Maybe there was a musical number. Maybe robots. If anyone has seen the whole thing, chime in.

With compliments,

Keith

Review of The Conspirator
Hot Toasty Rag, September 25, 2017

The Conspirator is a courtroom drama about those involved in Abraham Lincolns assassination. Major history buffs might already know the tidbits presented in this story, but I was a political science major in college, and even I was surprised by parts of the plot.

Seven men are on trial, as well as one woman, the mother of one of the co-conspirators. The only man who steps up as a defense lawyer for the accused is the young and inexperienced James McAvoy, and he comes across countless obstacles as he tries to give Robin Wright her right to a fair trial.

If you didn't know Robert Redford directed this movie, you would probably think to yourself, James McAvoy must really like Robert Redford! As it is, Im sure he does like Robert Redford, as does the rest of the all-star cast, since stars famously vie to work for the father of Sundance. If you close your eyes during some of the courtroom speeches, it almost sounds like Redford himself is talking. I think the directorial influence on the leading actor is rather cute, and its easy to imagine that had this movie been made thirty years earlier, the defense lawyer would probably have been blond.

The Conspirator has beautiful, realistic set and costume design, and the men in the castMcAvoy, Kevin Kline, Tom Wilkinson, and Colm Meaneyseem authentic in their surroundings. My biggest complaint about the film are the ladies. Neither Robin Wright, nor Evan Rachel Wood, and especially not Alexis Bledel, seem like they belonged in the 1860s. Trying to ignore Bledels contemporary face and voice is impossible, but thankfully she has a very tiny part. Wood also feels very contemporary, the way she moves and the patter of her speech. And even though Wright has a plain face and doesnt sound like a California valley girl, she still seems contemporary. Women were treated differently back then, and a woman her age would have a completely different aura from decades of living in the 1800s. Wright feels like an independent woman who has never been mistreated or disrespected.

That criticism aside, if you like that era of history, this is a very good movie to watch. Robert Redford is an excellent director, and its very fun to see McAvoy project his essence in the lead role.

When it comes to the story of Mary Surratt, everyone knows how the story ends.  You may not know the name, but you will recall who she was:  she ran the boarding house in which John Wilkes Booth & his cronies devised plans to assassinate President Abraham Lincoln, Vice President Andrew Johnson and Secretary of State William Seward.  {While it was not mentioned in the movie, I believe they also conspired to assassinate Ulysses S. Grant as well}.  Everyone assumed that she "had" to know what was going on, given that she owned the boarding house.

While everyone knows how the story ends,  almost nobody outside the esoteric realm of civil war era historians are familiar with the intricacies of her case.......until now.  The present movie takes the viewer back in time to 1865.  The civil war is over, but it will claim one last high ranking casualty:  Abraham Lincoln.  Seward was stabbed several times, but he lived.  Andrew Johnson escaped the plot to kill him unscathed.  The entire country wanted revenge.  There was also a fear that anything short of a swift show of might would embolden other southerners to try an insurrection.  These were delicate times.

Such is the backdrop of the present movie.  It questions where a person's right to a fair trial is usurped by that nagging variable known as political expediency.  Should anyone ever be used as a judicial sacrificial lamb?  The storyline has obvious overtones which parallel our own times.  We have a great many people accused of terrorism that we are holding @ Gitmo.  They are not even American citizens.  Do they have rights?  If so, what rights to we grant them?  When we have pundits on FOX NEWS espousing that we should just "skip the trials & shoot them" the didactic point of the present movie strikes home.

For people who have read Plato and / or have an interest in the concept of justice, this disc is highly recommended.  For civil era buffs, this film is an absolute must-have.  Was Mary Surratt guilty or innocent?  You decide ~ but watch this movie 1st.

I applaud the creators of the film for attempting to be as historically accurate as possible, but I was disappointed that nothing was portrayed about Lincoln's Vice President, Andrew Johnson, in the film.  He played a very important part in Mary Surratt's story, and in the assassination of Lincoln.  Much pressure was placed on him to commute Mary's sentence to imprisonment, many military officers and politicians didn't want the stigma of executing a woman.  Mary's daughter Anna, as well as family members of the others accused, attempted to plead their case with Andrew Johnson at the White House several times, but were refused admittance.  Also, on the day of the assassination John Wilkes Booth left a calling card in Andrew Johnson's "message box" at the hotel he was living at, and it's always been a mystery as to what connection he had with Booth.  Not to mention the fact that Andrew Johnson was supposed to be the third government official to be assassinated in the conspiracy... (with Lincoln and Seward) but his would-be assassin "chickened out" at the last minute.  All of this history was left out of the film.  For that reason I give the film a 4 instead of a 5.

3 1/2 stars -- this is a nice costume drama with a timely flavor, but it lacks a bit in intensity.  It's the story of Mary Surratt (Robin Wright), mother of one of the conspirators in Lincoln's assassination (and the attempted assassination of the Vice-President and Secretary of State), and the effort to defend her by the young lawyer (and former Union officer) Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy).  It becomes clear early to Aiken that the government wants to execute Surratt as a way of discouraging those few Confederate soldiers who are continuing to fight on, even after Lee's surrender.  I call it timely, for at the time of its release in 2010, the issue in the US was very much the question of what was justified in the name of national security, as the former members of the Bush administration sought to justify harsh measures and even torture against terrorist suspects and to justify too the treatment of them in special courts outside the civilian justice system.  In "The Conspirator," there is also military court, and it seems quite obvious that Aiken's maneuvering as a defense lawyer is going to be quite limited.  It doesn't help that Secretary of War Edwin Stanton (Kevin Kline) has his thumb firmly on the scales of justice, and it is he who articulates quite unapologetically the idea that since the Union is still in danger, justice might have to take a back seat to expediency.  He's not above pressuring witnesses and suborning perjury, and as Aiken tries to defend his client in these circumstances, his own loyalty comes into question, despite his having been a wounded and honorably-serving veteran.  By the end, suffice it to say, Aiken is thoroughly disillusioned by the law and its susceptibility to political manipulation.

These issues are important, so it's a pity that the movie is so low-key.  Nobody does a bad job -- with Robin Wright being perhaps the most compelling performer -- but it seems more interested in setting out the issues than in engaging us with them vividly via drama.  A movie like this should make its points, of course, but when, in the course of the movie, you feel the points being checked off, then something is missing.  Robert Redford directs with efficiency, and the story lines are clear, but in his earlier "Quiz Show," for example, the legal setting and the acting generated some heat.  Here we have light without the heat, and if it's not really all that bad, it's nonetheless not up to Redford's best or the best of the very fine cast, whom we've seen being much more engaging in other movies.

From a historical vantage you do get the core nugget of truth, that Mary Surratt, an American citizen and a civilian was tried by a military tribunal (in kangaroo court fashion), with little due process and with complete disregard for the truth.

This movie however also disregards the truth. It focuses on one of Mrs. Surratt's attorneys, fictionalizing an account of his crusade to defend his client. The fact is that Mrs. Surratt's attorneys gave her a dreadful defense, and she bemoaned this fact all the way to the gallows.

This movie lost focus. The true facts of these rag tag conspirators led by a narcissistic and psychotic stage actor would have made for a fascinating movie. Anyone with a passing knowledge of American history knows that Abraham Lincoln was assassinated by actor John Wilkes Booth. What ISN'T commonly known is that Booth was part of a ring of Confederate conspirators.

And one of the most important trials of the 19th century comes to life in "The Conspirator," Robert Redford's dramatization of the trial of Mary Surratt and the men who conspired with Booth. James McAvoy and Robin Wright both give stellar performances as a clever young lawyer and a woman railroaded by an angry, vengeful government, but the direction often loses its energy and becomes rather flat and stagey.

In 1865, the Civil War has just ended and the North is celebrating its victory. But then assassins are sent to attack the Secretary of State and the Vice President. And at a play that Lincoln is attending, Booth (Toby Kebbell) shoots the president, shouts "Sic Semper Tyrannis! The South is avenged!" and somehow manages to escape the theatre. The dying Lincoln is taken to a nearby house, and dies shortly after. The conspirators are hunted down, and Booth is killed when they are burned out of the barn where they are hiding.

One of the suspects is Mary Surratt (Wright), the mother of one conspirator and the owner of a boardinghouse where they met. Since the government is determined to punish as many people as possible, she is presumed by everyone -- including former soldier/up-and-coming lawyer Frederick Aiken (McAvoy) -- to be completely guilty.

Then Aiken finds himself in the horrible position of having to defend her, even though he doesn't doubt her guilt. But her innocence or guilt soon become less certain in his mind, even as he realizes that the trial of the suspects is not a true trial -- witnesses are bribed or threatened, and the prosecution refuses to even consider that Mary might not have been a conspirator. As Aiken's life and career fall apart, he throws himself into the last desperate attempts to save her from the hangman's noose.

While obviously the assassination of Lincoln was an important moment in American history, "The Conspirator" looks at the smaller, groundbreaking changes that happened because of it -- namely, the first execution of a white woman by the federal government, and the new right of a civilian trial instead of a merely-a-formality-before-we-hang-everyone military tribunal. It's a sobering reminder that government corruption is nothing new, and that basic rights like a proper trial by one's peers must be fought for constantly, not just once.

As the backdrop to this drama, Redford does an excellent job portraying the fractured, fragile nature of a post-Civil War United States -- there's an undercurrent of seething rage and pain from both sides, glazed over with Washington parties and jaunts to elegant theatres. And the depiction of Lincoln's final hours is absolutely riveting, with the desperate and hysterical citizens crowding outside the building where he dies, surrounded by dead-eyed, hopeless officials and doctors.

Unfortunately, the movie loses a lot of its energy after the first half hour. After that first burst of energy, Mary and the conspirators are all captured and... it simply becomes very very contemplative and stagey, more like a play than a proper movie. Redford doesn't seem to quite know how to inject suspense into the courtroom drama scenes, relying mostly on the occasional outburst from Wright or McAvoy to give it some passion. So for long stretches, it just sort of drags itself along, floating Aiken through subplots that aren't very interesting (such as his visit to Mary's daughter).

McAvoy and Wright both give excellent performances here, as world-weary people who hail from opposite sides of a war that has blistered them both -- he is a fierce young lawyer whose love of justice overrides any blind loyalty to the War Department, and she is a quiet, tormented enigma whose guilt or innocence is never entirely clear. There are some solid performances by Evan Rachel Wood, Colm Meaney, Tom Wilkensen and Danny Huston, but the story effectively revolves around those two actors and the oddly combative chemistry they share.

"The Conspirator" is graced with some excellent performances and a great setting, but Robert Redford's stage-like story seems to lose its momentum after the first half hour, making it a chore to sit through some of the story. A fascinating if flawed story.

Director and producer Robert Redford shows that the debates we have today on the relevancy of Constitutional rights during exceptional times like war or acts of terror are not new, but occupy a significant part of the American experience--although an often ignored part.

The film is based on the true story of the military trial of Mary Surrat, one of the accused conspirators in the Lincoln assassination. Surrat (played by Robin Wright) was unfortunate enough to own the boarding house where several of the conspirators met--including her son. A military court is ordered by Secretary of War Edwin Stanton, one of the most infamous characters in Lincoln's cabinet. It was Stanton who ordered and oversaw, with Lincoln's approval, the mass arrests and imprisonment of thousands of American citizens during the war. Most of those imprisoned were newspaper editors and reporters, anti-war (or anti-Lincoln) Democrats, alleged Southern sympathizers, and simply anyone the government wanted out of the way.

Stanton now orchestrates a kangaroo court to provide an angry and paranoid nation with swift "justice" for the accused and "healing for the nation."

The military court is selected by Stanton. The accused are not allowed to testify in their own defense. Surrat herself is kept in solitary confinement under constant guard. Oddly enough, the attorney chosen to represent Surrat is a former Union war hero lately turned lawyer, Captain Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy). Aiken is chosen by his firm to represent Surrat because he is not a Southerner. He is a reluctant defender completely prejudiced against Surrat at the beginning.

But as the mock trial commences, Aiken is troubled by the complete lack of regard for constitutional protections and due process owed his client. Witnesses are threatened, attorney/client privilege is suspended, and false witnesses are brought forward to accuse Surrat. Aiken becomes disillusioned that the country he fought four years to defend is allowing such a mockery of justice to an American citizen.

Meanwhile, Aiken loses friends daily as war fever rages and anyone not walking in lockstep with Stanton's policies is considered seditious and unpatriotic. At one point, Aiken confronts Secretary Stanton about the injustice of the case, and Stanton reminds him of a primary argument that Lincoln himself used in defending the Civil War: the rights enjoyed by Americans are not as important as the security of the nation itself.

Lincoln was confronted early in the war by opponents in Congress who asked him to justify the multiple constitutional violations being perpetrated by the administration. Lincoln responded that he was violating part of the Constitution in order to prevent the whole of it being violated by the "rebels."

The confusing, purely political logic of Lincoln would be easily flagged by the historian enjoying the advantage of hindsight if Lincoln's position had not later been recycled by Stanton, Woodrow Wilson, FDR, LBJ, Bush I and II, Obama, and basically anyone wanting a trump card over the "Supreme Law of the Land." Americans are historically so conditioned to "exceptions" to Constitutional freedoms and guarantees that the exceptions have become the rule.

Redford shows great wisdom and depth by selecting the Surrat case as the stage on which he presents his audience with the horrible consequences of a "government by expediency." The idolatrous devotion of Americans to the "Lincoln myth" would make it impossible for Redford to make his point had he chosen any number of equally tragic cases that took place prior to Mary Surrat's during the Civil War. But Redford wisely picks an easy moral case. Surrat was a widow and a single parent who was in the wrong place at the wrong time in a post-Lincoln regime governed by easy villains who not one in a thousand Americans could name in a lineup today.

Captain Aiken easily shows that the government can only prove beyond a shadow of doubt that Surrat is guilty of nothing more than being the mother of one of the suspected conspirators. Yet the government argues that the "interests of the nation" must be placed ahead of the rights of the individual. Stanton argues that too much blood has already been shed. If Surrat is freed, then the nation risks further unrest and a continuation of war. It may be wrong to execute Mary Surrat, but it would be worse not to execute her. In the end, the cowardice and fear of men (who should have protected the innocent and weak) allowed Mary Surrat to be hung by the neck until dead.

At the end of the film, Redford inserts a post script before the credits, pointing out that the US Supreme Court ruled one year later (in Ex parte Milligan) that American citizens could not be tried in a military court--even during war time. So the audience is left with some assurance that Surrat's case was a recognized exception and her death not entirely in vain.

But, alas, Redford's charitable desire to provide some relief to his morally indignant audience is muted in those of us who did not fall asleep during our postbellum American history classes. The US Supreme Court ruling in Milligan took place in 1866. But the radical Republican-controlled Congress passed the first of several Reconstruction Acts in 1867. These acts effectively abolished the Southern states, divided the South into five military districts, and put the whole region under marshal law. When Congress feared retribution by the Supreme Court, it simply abolished the Habeus Corpus Act and removed the issue from the Court's jurisdiction. The fit of madness that condemned Mary Surrat to death would last another 10 years. Some believe it has never fully ended.
A great film that may counteract the filmmaker's intentions by illuminating why Constitutional authority, and the rule of law, may be far superior to bullying, morally superior "leadership."

Like most Robert Redford films, this movie about the trial of Lincoln's assassination conspirators is historically meticulous and dramatically rich, but also slow-moving and frequently under-played in key moments. In the extra features, Redford said he was going for a deliberately musty look to the sets, unfortunately resulting in an "Antiques Roadshow" vibe that weighs the film down like a lead ball while leaching the visceral impact of every scene. But the film is certainly well-cast with many familiar TV and cinema faces. James McAvoy is good as the idealistic young lawyer assigned to defend Mary Surratt, a Southern Catholic widow who ran the boarding house where John Wilkes Booth and friends planned the death of Abraham Lincoln, leaving herself as the only female conspirator charged in military court with treason. Redford analogizes the post-assassination backlash of 1865 to present-day abuse of civil liberties. Rather than taking sides for or against Surratt, played here with iron resolve by Robin Wright Penn, Redford lets her remain distant, trying to suggest her guilt and innocence simultaneously. Ironically, the greater historicity here means weakened drama, for which Redford relies on Kevin Kline in a clearly villainous role as War Secretary Edwin Stanton. It creates a weird sense of disconnect to see Stanton consistently played as a villain while Surratt is played as an enigma rather than hero. It's a good film, but not great. Daniel Day-Lewis probably did a better job in "Lincoln" because of his efforts to provide insights into Lincoln's character. This film refuses to give us real insight into anyone except McAvoy, whose gradual transformation comes across here as a touch more self-righteous than genuine. The film should have been about the titular Mary Surratt, not her lawyer.

As a movie: Even judged as a propaganda film, this is a bad movie. For "preaching to the choir", I would give it 3-stars ("It's OK"), but for the general audience, it is 1-star. Because of the script, most of the characters are little more than cardboard cut-outs. Only Robin Wright (as Mary Surratt) has presence as a character. The other main character is her lawyer Frederick Aiken (played by James McAvoy), but his role is primarily to be outraged, thereby serving as a vehicle for preaching at the audience. I quickly developed an unintended dislike for his character, which increased throughout the movie. The scenes are set-pieces and the flow is poor, resulting in a movie that feels slow-paced and meandering. There is no sense of grappling with the issues or alternatives -- there are only pronouncements and posturing. The movie doesn't rise to even the level of a mediocre episode of Law and Order. Also, many of the scenes do not feel authentic (beyond the costumes and sets). First, many of Aiken's diatribes feel incredibly modern, including things that you weren't likely to hear in 1965, much less in 1865 (I am both old enough and young enough to remember the 1960s). Second, the portrayal of the trial feels derivative of too many movies about military (show) trials, reinforcing my assessment below that the script wasn't driven by the history. Examples: Breaker Morant,Paths of Glory. ---- As history: This movie prominently advertises itself as presenting a true story, and this needs to be rebutted. If one watches the documentary in the Extras or reads the history, the kindest thing that can be said is that the movie "was inspired by actual events", or more accurately that it cherry-picked and distorted events. The viewer will likely have the false impression that this was a short, hurried trial (there was a long line of both prosecution and defense witnesses). That there was little evidence of her guilt. That Mary Surratt was badly mistreated, for example being denied visits by her daughter. ... The movie presents images that are virtually guaranteed to be misinterpreted. For example, the prisoners are shown with bags over their heads, invoking parallels to torture. However, those were _padded_ bags and were introduced in response to a suicide attempt, but apparently were also intended to keep the prisoners from communicating with each other. The bags did turn out to be painful, but I haven't seen anything that suggests that was intentional (above the level of the jailers putting on bags more tightly than needed). The documentary (in the Extras) briefly raises the point that much of the controversy about Mary Surratt's guilt was rooted not in the factual evidence, but in sexism -- that a woman wouldn't/couldn't do such a thing. Yet you won't see this in the movie even though it was a significant part of the trial (character witnesses, pleas for clemency, ...). In describing the response to the assassination, one of the movie's historians describes that assassination as unthinkable. Yet there had been multiple assassination attempts against Lincoln, starting before his inauguration. One of those historians repeatedly attributes Mary Surratt's execution to animosity against Catholics, yet never explains (beyond the existence of religious prejudices) and never mentions that there was a large population of Catholics in Maryland -- because it was founded as a colony as a refuge for Catholics (Aside: In case you are wondering, some of my ancestors came to the US as Protestants fleeing Catholics, some as Catholics fleeing Protestants, and some as Protestants fleeing other types of Protestants). One of the historians in the Extras took umbrage at the measures taken to keep the conspirators from escaping on the reasoning that they hadn't yet been convicted. This seems suggestive of the politics underlying the movie. Some of the historians in the documentary seem to be pushing political agendas. One talks about Sec of War Stanton pushing to get "a correct result" as if that was unconnected to justice. Yet the history of the investigation and the trial was one of focusing in on only the most central of the plotters -- many who were unquestionably Confederate sympathizers but were only minor facilitators of the plot were not prosecuted, and not all those convicted were executed. Yet the movie gives the strong impression that the political pressures was to execute persons without concern for their guilt. If so, why include a woman which was bound to be highly controversial? The presentation of the choice to use a military tribunal in both the included documentary and the movie fails to provide even a cursory appreciation for the problems of a civilian trial. For example, until the influx of Northerners during the Civil War, Washington DC was a decidedly Southern city and very pro-slavery (much of the Capitol Building construction used slave labor) and at the time of the trial still had very large pro-Confederacy elements -- the conspirators were hardly alone in this (Aside: neighboring Maryland was a slave state, and although it did not join the Confederacy, much of its population was pro-slavery). In a civilian trial, how would one credibly assemble a jury where there wouldn't be at least one juror who would ignore the facts and instead vote his pro-slavery politics? What would have been the results of a wrongful acquittal of the conspirators? Although the movie is based on the belief that politics determined the verdict, its rendering of the politics of the time is not to be taken seriously. It is minimal, simplistic and mostly wrong. ---- As an allegory: It is hard to believe that this movie is not intended primarily as a comment on military tribunals in the current "Global War on Terror", and was distorted to fill that role. Instead, the Lincoln assassination should be viewed as the opening act in a century of terrorism associated with the Ku Klux Klan (and its predecessors and similar organizations). With the defeat of the Confederate armies, the Union was desperate to keep the rebel troops from melting away and forming guerrilla bands and having the war likely continue for decades. While that was largely prevented, the South stepped down one notch on the insurgency intensity scale and resorted to a widespread campaign of terror to virtually re-institute slavery under other guises and to re-assert the economic and political power of large portions of the old slave-holding class. The North temporarily won the Civil War in 1865, but the South's near-total victory was completed by 1877 (with a few remaining pockets of resistance to be mopped up). Although the trial of Mary Surratt was hardly perfect, it was good-enough and justice was almost certainly done. And it showed a government that could respond effectively and intelligently to an extreme act of terror. It did not wildly and indiscriminately over-react, but implemented a limited, highly targeted response that was open to widespread press coverage and that produced a result that was timely without being rushed. Aside: In choosing to return to a quasi-feudal political and economic system that required the mass of the population -- white and black -- to be kept in poverty, the South consigned itself to be an impoverished region for decades. That system was broken by what could be regarded as the Second Reconstruction: Starting with FDR, the federal government deliberately pumped massive subsidies into the Southern economy (military bases, TVA...). This was followed by education reform, voting rights... So why wasn't this the allegory chosen by Redford et al?? -- Douglas B. Moran

The Conspirator is a star studded period piece concerning the kangaroo court trial of those involved in the Lincoln assassination, specifically the rather thin case against Mary Surratt, played by the usually brilliant Robin Wright. Historical accuracy or inaccuracy is not my main point of analysis. While obvious characterizations are whole or partially fictitious, the circumstances, Surratt's guilt or innocence and the depth of the pro-Southern conspiracy, are open to historical debate. Therefore, this film is merely an interpretation. However, it is simply flat. Directed by Robert Redford and brimming with talent, it has no logical right to be as lifeless as it felt to me. I can't help but compare it to Spielberg's Lincoln, where political conversation and intrigue is gripping and evocative or Spielberg's earlier historical courtroom drama, Amistad. Compared to those films, the finely crafted sets, costuming, and casting of The Conspirator is dragged down by its lack of passion and its rather drab style. The subject matter is ripe for overblown melodrama or opportunities for taut historical commentary. The Conspirator lands disappointingly in the middle.

Robert Redford's "The Conspirator" (2010) is about the only woman to be charged as a co-conspirator in Lincoln's assassination. Mary Surratt (Robin Wright) ran the boarding house where her son, John (Johnny Simmons), regularly met with John Wilkes Booth and others plotting their seditious deeds. Mary Claims she simply ran a boarding house and didn't know what her tenants and their friends were hatching. The young lawyer assigned to defend her, Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy), knows that she probably knew more, but also that there's not enough evidence to convict her and, by extension, execute her.

The film starts with Lincoln's assassination and the search for Booth, but then settles into a courtroom drama. I found the first half engrossing enough for a historical drama, but it was the second half that really hooked me in when I discovered that "The Conspirator" wasn't just about the Surratt family. It's just as much about Aiken's determination to do what's right, whatever the cost, and the consequences of this decision.

At only 27 years of age, I'm sure those who assigned Aiken the job of defending Mary Surratt weren't expecting much, especially since he fought for the North and despised the rebellion. He was a puppet expected to just go-through-the-motions of defending Surratt. But, as Aiken discovers that there's really not enough evidence to convict Mary and observes the outright corruption of the prosecution, Aiken understands that there's more than just Mary Surratt's life at stake. If she could be railroaded and executed so easily in the land of the free, anyone could.

But there's a hefty price for doing what's right if it goes against the grain of popular opinion.

Alexis Bledel also stars as Aiken's woman and Evan Rachel Wood as Mary's daughter, both excellent.

The film was shot in Georgia and runs 122 minutes.

FINAL SAY: "The Conspirator" does exactly what a good historical drama should do -- it takes the viewer back into the historical world of the characters and does it effectively and realistically. It also prompts you to look into the facts of the real-life events afterward. Even more, the potent subtexts are driven home.

GRADE: B+

The assassination of Abraham Lincoln at the end of our Civil War was probably one of the most emotionally and politically traumatizing events in our history up to that time. Lincoln, almost universally considered our best and most effective president, had led the country through the War; and Lee's army had just recently surrendered. In the aftermath of assassination, virtually everyone who had any connection to, or association with, John Wilkes Booth, the primary conspirator, was rounded up and incarcerated. There was a government-directed effort to rush to judgement...to get past the trial; punish the offenders; and return the country to normalcy ASAP. To expedite the trial, a military tribunal was used...the civilian perpetrators were tried in a military court, without benefit of trial by jury. Mary Surratt, who ran the boarding house where the conspirators met, was arrested and charged with conspiracy too and this fine historical drama tells her story. One of the conspirators, still at large, was her son, John, and the thinking was that charging and trying his mother would flush him out. It didn't, John Surratt was tried by jury a year later and walked. This is the first film produced by the American Film Company, which was founded on the noble belief that historical films are more compelling than fiction. It was masterfully crafted by Robert Redford behind the camera and features superb performances by Robin Wright as Mary Surratt; and James McAvoy, as her defense lawyer, Frederick Aiken. Evan Rachel Wood, Alexis Bledel, Tom Wilkinson and Kevin Kline deliver fine performances too in support roles. Hopefully this is just the first of other films of this nature to be produced during the sesquicentennial anniversary years of the Civil War. This one carries my highest recommendation.

"The Conspirator" is the first film produced by American Film Company established in 2008, and if you watch the film's end credits closely (or visit the company's homepage), you know the new studio is primarily interested in making historically accurate films based on American history.

The story itself is an intriguing one. Set in post-Civil War Washington, "The Conspirator" is about a young attorney Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy), who reluctantly defends Mary Surratt (Robin Wright), a boarding house owner who was accused of harboring the men responsible for the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

Directed by Robert Redford, the film spends considerable time following the change that happens in Frederick, from an indifferent and inexperienced young lawyer to a passionate and dedicated one. His transformation is convincing, largely thanks to James McAvoy's effecting performance, but with courtroom drama that often feels rushed, "The Conspirator" as a historical drama sometimes seems not really interested in whether Mary is "guilty" - legally or morally - or not. Great court-room movies are always about more than just the case.  They are usually an intertwining of multiple stories, all of which affect the case itself.  This can be said of this movie.  The title of the movie refers to Mary Surrat, who was tried and convicted of being part of the conspiracy to kill Abraham Lincoln.  Her case and her defense by Union war hero Frederick Aiken is only one key part of the movie.  Another key part is the internal tension within Mr. Aiken in trying to determine her innocence or guilt, and his conflicts with Mary and her daughter in trying to get them to tell him the truth.  This drama itself rivals that of the courtroom.  Smaller story-lines include the conflicts between Mr. Aiken and his peers, which include his girlfriend, his friends at a local gentleman's club, and the machinations of Secretary of War Edwin Stanton.  The movie is anchored by great acting from numerous roles.  Lifelong comic actor Kevin Kline turns in a good performance as Edwin Stanton.  James McAvoy does a wonderful job playing lawyer Frederick Aiken, a character whose internal turmoil is only surpassed by the conflicts he has with those around him.  Probably the best acting is done by the two actresses; Robin Wright playing the "Conspirator", and Evan Rachel Wood playing her daughter.  The former sacrifices herself to protect her son, who she knows was intimately involved in a plot to kidnap President Lincoln.  The latter is convinced to turn against her brother to try and save her mother; to no avail.  All told, a great drama set in the aftermath of two of the most important events in US history; the Civil War and the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

An attempt is made to humanize the conspirators, namely Mrs. Surrat, but does so to little effect.  We see no real connection between her and her children, only a story of their drunken father and her attempts to make a living told within the cold stone walls of her prison cell.

Whether she was guilty or not, we may never truly know.  Many versions of her story abound, but in the end, history is written from the standpoint of the victors. We all know - or should know - that.  Evidence has even been presented suggesting Boothe survived long after Lincoln's assassination, evidence with historical backing, but like the evidence in Surrat's case, it has been buried once more.

This could easily turn into an argument of defending assassins, conspirators and such, but the greatest lesson to come from this movie remains.  That lesson is that from Mrs. Surrat's trial came the defense of one of our greatest rights:  The right to a trial by jury in peacetime OR war.  She may have been guilty, but the process of her trial was unfair and unconstitutional.

I don't "blame the government" as some one star reviewers suggest. I'm not anti-government. In fact, I am grateful that at long last, decent officials finally realized the injustice of Mrs. Surrat's trial and they agreed to stand for the rights of all by declaring trials like hers would not happen again.

This movie should be viewed as entertainment first, given historical inaccuracies (even the best historical movie has them), but secondly as a chance for us to delve deeper into history. Movies like this one should prompt us to think, to discuss and more importantly to LEARN not just the "victor's" point of view, but also the "loser's."

All that said, please allow me to interject what I feel is a bit of humor.  At 1:07 in the movie, listen for the modern sounding toilet as Aiken waits to speak with Johnson.  It's just a wee bit out of place, don't you think?

These elements are drawn together in this movie which explores a dark coda to the Lincoln assasination: the military tribunal which tried the conspirators. The film focuses upon Fredrick Aiken, a former Union officer and lawyer, who is drawn, rather against his will, into defending one of the alleged conspirators, Mary Surrat, the owner of the boarding house where John Wilkes Booth met with his co-conspirators.

This facinating story is not well known, and Redford has drawn from it clear parallels with some of the contemporary abuses of American power that wartime has brought.

I think James McAvoy is one of the most exciting actors alive and here he delivers one of his trademark ham-free performances as Aiken. The rest of the international cast delivers fine support, particularly the great Kevin Kline, brilliantly convincing as Edwin Stanton, the War Secretary, whose single-mindedness in prosecuting the war to preserve the Union threatens the very principles of the Union in the absence of Lincoln's wise authority.

In summary this is a thoughtful, tense and at times very moving courtroom and civil war drama that celebrates moral courage where others have focussed on the physical variety. Vastly better than most of what is available at the multiplex of a weekend.

The film itself is an interesting bit of unknown history, unknown at least to me. The Conspirator tells the story of Mary Surratt (Wright), the mother of John Surratt, a known associate of President Lincoln's assassin, actor John Wilkes Booth.  Apparently, since the U.S. could not try Booth himself, having been shot to death days after the deed, a tribunal court was formed by the War Department to try Mary Surratt for her role in the conspiracy to assassinate President Lincoln, Vice President Andrew Johnson and Secretary of State William H. Seward.

James McAvoy plays Fredrick Aiken, a war hero, fresh from fighting for the Union in the Civil War, charged with defending Mary Surratt. His task is a nearly impossible one, as the country wants blood as payment for the loss of the beloved President.  McAvoy is a weak link in the story, as his portrayal is lightweight.  Aiken appears as though he's unconcerned with the outcome, despite the dialogue and the punishments he faces from friends and society.  There is no urgency in the performance.

The story is smart and pretty fascinating, but unfortunately the script is choppy, as it drags in some places and paces much too quickly in others.  It makes for an odd viewing experience at times.  I would have liked to have seen more focus on the conspiracy itself, as much of the trial is spoken of, but barely seen only in very brief flashbacks.  Characters are introduced then cast aside, never to be seen again.  Others are talked about, but hardly seen, adding to the cloudiness of the proceedings.

The majority of the cast (with the aforementioned exception of McAvoy and a severely miscast Justin Long) are very good carrying out their historical roles, both famous and infamous.  Kevin Kline is almost unrecognizable as the man behind the tribunal, Edwin Stanton.  He makes the most of his brief time on screen and is memorably villainous.  Wilkinson is also only briefly onscreen as Aiken's mentor, Reverdy Johnson.  He is solid as usual.  I've never been a huge fan of Robin Wright.  Her turn as Jenny in Forrest Gump, always struck me as a blemish in an otherwise classic film.  She is fine here, as she doesn't have much to do but look sad.

As a whole, the film, directed by superstar Robert Redford, is a intriguing curiosity of a tumultuous time in our nation's history.

Maybe he was taking into account that many who might watch this film are not history buffs or do not know much about the assassination conspiracy?  Mary Surratt was a VERY involved participant in the planning of the 1864 kidnap plot and in the subsequent assassination plan.  She could have turned the participants in to the Federal authorities at any time but yet she chose not to.  Of course, this would have meant turning in her own son, John Surratt, Jr. as well, who was John Wilkes Booth's right-hand man.  As Andrew Johnson remarked, "She kept the nest that hatched the egg" referring to the boarding house that Mary kept on H Street in Washington, D.C. where the conspirators frequently met to plan their heinous plot.  As to Mary being tried by a military tribunal as opposed to a civilian trial, what she and the others did was an act of war against the United States as the Civil War was still going on, although in its final stages.  They were Southerners who were upset at Lincoln's reelection in 1864 and General Lee's surrender to General Grant at Appomattox Court House days earlier.  By targeting the President, Vice President, and Secretary of War for assassination, they were attempting to decapitate the Federal government.  They were not entitled to a civilian trial any more than the 9/11 terrorists would have been.  Watch this movie for entertainment value only and then read "American Brutus" or "Blood on the Moon" for an accurate and honest account of the Lincoln assassination conspiracy plot.

This is a serious film about a topic that is just as relevant today as it was in 1865, and with question of capital punishment added to the mix, it is just as important today as ever. Thoughtful, intelligent, and probing.

"The Conspirator" is NOT an entertainment. I'm hardly the first to say so; most of the 80-some reviews already posted have taken note of the film's political agenda. I have no doubt that director Robert Redford and script writer James Solomon intended a connection to be understood between the suspension of habeas corpus in 1863, during the Civil War, and the assaults on civil liberties of the Bush/Cheney neo-conservatives in the name of national security. Yes, there are points of relevant comparison, but unfortunately there are overlapping agendas. I'd love to avoid ranking this preachment-disguised-as-a-film with stars, but I can't. So, it gets one star for muddle or five stars for good intentions, but understand, please, that the ranking is arbitary and could go either way. Therefore, my three stars ... a 'mugwump' solution if ever!

First I have to be honest about my own agendas. I'm opposed to capital punishment for any crime under any circumstances, although my opposition is totally rational rather than emotional. There are acts so unspeakably hideous that I would relish shredding the perpetrators with a cheese-grater, but I don't believe judicial murder serves the good of society. The hanging of Mary Surratt, the climax of this film, is patently intended to draw my/your sympathy to a woman who may have been unfairly tried and unjustly punished. Had I been one of the panel of judges in 1865, I would not have voted for her execution, nor for the execution of the other three convicted plotters. I would have stuck with my conscience. But the sympathy for Mary Surratt is merely a ploy in this film, a distractor, a red herring if you will. In fact, the evidence against Mary Surratt is far more than circumstantial. She was guilty, in that she certainly knew what was being plotted. Even Redford and Solomon can't help allowing for her guilt. So the "agenda" here isn't opposition to capital punishment or supposition that Mary Surratt was innocent.

That brings us back to Bush/Cheney. And that puts me on the spot, because I fiercely agree with the implications of the film. Bush/Cheney violated the provisions of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights. The prison camp at Guantanamo, the use of torture, the kidnappings -- all villainies and violations of the best American ideals! Take a look at the other one/two star reviews of The Conspirator, and you'll find that supporters of the Bush/Cheney doctrines denounce the film's agenda. And here I am, supporting that agenda yet disapproving of the film! What's up?

John Surratt Jr., Mary's son, fled from Washington before the assassination which he had certainly helped to plot. James McAvoy does a sterling performance as Suratt's lawyer Frederick Aiken. Makeup and period costuming disguise Kevin Kline's excellent performance as Edwin Stanton. "Those who would give up essential Liberty, to purchase a little temporary Safety, deserve neither Liberty nor Safety." - Benjamin Franklin.

One could change Benjamin Franklin's quote to read as "Those who would give up civil rights to guarantee justice, deserve neither." Injustice in the name of justice serves as the essential underpinning of The American Film Company's debut film, "The Conspirator," directed by Robert Redford.

"The Conspirator" is the story of the trial of Mary Surratt who was executed for her role in the conspiracy to assassinate, President Abraham Lincoln, Vice President Andrew Johnson and Secretary of State William H. Seward. "It is a story nobody knows wrapped up in a story that everyone knows," says Redford.

The guilt or innocence of Mary Surratt has been debated among historians since her execution, and will continue to be.  Her complicity in the assassination conspiracy is not the story that screenwriters James Solomon & Gregory Bernstein, nor director Robert Redford set out to tell, but rather they concentrate on her trial as a civilian by a military tribunal.

Robin Wright portrays a stoic Mary Surratt who has accepted her fate, the authorities of the United States government having left nothing to chance.  Her silent strength certainly aids the audience in their empathy toward her.  She is originally defended by Reverdy Johnson, a United States Senator from Maryland (played by the always dependable English actor Tom Wilkinson), but for whatever reason Johnson has given the job of Mrs. Surratt's defense to his young associate, and veteran of the Union Army, Frederick Aiken.

Aiken, played by Scottish actor James McAvoy, is convinced of Mrs. Surratt's guilt. He is at first openly hostile towards her, but as he comes to realize the fairness of the trial of his client by a military tribunal is a sham.  Mrs. Surratt as the defendant is not allowed to testify on her own behalf, and there is no right to appeal.  Finally he admits to a friend, "I don't know whether she is guilty or innocent."

The supporting cast is equally as strong as the film's two lead actors; prosecutor Joseph Holt, played by Danny Huston; Edwin M. Stanton, United States Secretary of War, and puppet-master of the trial of the conspirators is sternly played by Kevin Kline; and Mary Surratt's daughter Anna, played by Evan Rachel Wood, at first displays the stoicism of her mother, but gives in to waves of emotion when first her mother is convicted and then taken to the gallows to be hung for her part in the conspiracy.

Director Robert Redford and the screenwriters do not dwell on the details of the assassination conspiracy, nor the hunt for Lincoln's assassin, John Wilkes Booth.  Neither is the subject of this movie.  But instead they allude to both in montages briefly showing the assassination, and the eventual killing of Booth.

One aspect that Redford does concentrate on is the chaos in the street outside Ford's Theater immediately following the assassination, and how they got Lincoln across the street and into the Peterson House, which I found very moving.

Of course a story about a trial of a civilian by a military tribunal is as relevant today as it was 145 years ago, and there are plenty of inferences to be made about the political agendas and motives of the film-makers.  We all have political views, and we are lucky enough to be living in the United States where the First Amendment of the Constitution guarantees the right of freedom of speech and the Fifth Amendment which guarantees due process of law to its citizens.

There are, however, a few small historical inaccuracies here and there, but any one going to a movie to expect an historically accurate movie, deserve neither accurate history, nor two hours of entertainment.

OK, almost everyone knows that John Wilkes Booth shot President Lincoln as he sat in Ford's Theatre. THE CONSPIRATOR is the true story of Mrs. Surrat's legal ordeal and her trial before a military tribunal while the nation (at least the Northern states) grieved the loss of its leader and demanded vengeance, masquerading as 'justice,' for this heinous act of terror.

Directed by Robert Redford and starring Robin Wright as Mary Surrat and James MacAvoy as her inexperienced defense attorney, THE CONSPIRATOR is a compelling historical drama with poignant undertones that continue to sound throughout our legal system and our national psyche.  After our own decade of fear following an act of unspeakable terror, this remarkable film shows us how the better nature of our selves was born in the aftermath of a national blood lust.  Compellingly watchable, this is a film that will raise questions long after the final fade-to-black and confronts us with a piece of our history that still resonates in our 9-11 world.

The collector's edition, the one you should buy, contains extras that enhance the viewing experience, and make a remarkable piece of work truly compelling.  THE CONSPIRATOR pays attention to period details that strengthen the story, but is careful to let that story unfold at its own pace without chest-thumping or finger-pointing.  So buy this, watch it, and talk about it with your friends.  You'll learn a little about our own history, but even more importantly, you'll also learn more about who we are as Americans and the principles we live by.  That's a lot for one film to promise; but trust me:  THE CONSPIRATOR delivers.

I've read this book and reviewed it here and had some issues with it, but generally I felt it managed to stay true to the story of what is normally referred to as the Lincoln Conspirators. Let me explain. While John Wilkes Booth is considered Lincoln's assasin, a group of men and one woman (Mrs. Mary Surratt) were implicated with helping Booth to execute Lincoln's murder. Booth was shot and killed at Garrett's barn in Virginia about 2 weeks or so after escaping the Capital and temporarily avoiding capture. As the government investigated the plot to kill Lincoln, several names came up of people who were complicite in achieving to kill Lincoln and effectively attempting to bring down the government. In some cases, it was easy to connect conspirators to specific acts. In the case of Mrs. Surratt, who claimed she had no knowledge of any plans, it was not that clearcut.

Many years ago when I was in the 6th Grade, I ordered a book about the Lincoln Assassination at school. Although the book was supposed to be intended for young readers, I vividly remembered the graphic picture of four hooded conspirators--3 men and 1 woman--hanging from the gallows. Thus began my fascination with the Lincoln Assassination and the conspiracy that changed history.
Most Americans know that John Wilkes Booth fatally shot Abraham Lincoln in Ford's Theater. Few know his assassination was part of a much grander scheme to totally cripple the US Government with the assassination of the three top US government officials - the President, The Vice-President and the Secretary of State. The ensuing chaos could have brought down the Union government and forever changed the history of the United States.

Robert Redford has done a remarkable job in trying to tell a part of the story in a historically accurate manner as possible. THE CONSPIRATOR is a brilliantly staged depiction of a turning point in American history. The movie basically deals with the story of Mary Surrat, a 42-year-old widow who runs a modest boarding house in Washington, D.C.,. Nothing out of the ordinary at first until we learn she is the mother of one of the conspirators and that John Wilkes Booth and other conspirators were frequent visitors to her boarding house. Mary Surrat becomes one of the accused and she and the surviving conspirators are charged in a military court NOT a civil court. Most of their civil rights are suspended in a trial where a guilty verdict is a certainty.

THE CONSPIRATOR draws in actual historical documents to tell its tragic story. Was Mary Surrat innocent and her only crime was running the boarding house where the conspirators met and schemed? Of did she play a more active role? Could she have warned the authorities of the impending plan to assassinate the President and two others. Through the years, history has taken a kinder look at Surrat but that vision has changed in recent years and THE CONSPIRATOR does a great job in presenting the facts and bringing a feel for the day as people worried that even a grander conspiracy was in the works.

Mary Surrat's innocence or degree of guilt will never be known for sure but her story is an amazing tale of injustice. There never was a chance for a fair trial. The verdicts were known before the trial began. THE CONSPIRATOR is more a story of the trial than of the actual events of that April night. The movie can get dry and ineffectual as we watch the courtroom proceedings. The action scenes are kept to a minimum as we see President Lincoln shot and Secretary of State Seward--recovering from a near fatal carriage accident--brutally stabbed to within an inch of his life. Vice President Andrew Johnson is spared as one of the conspirators is unable to do his chosen deed.

There is so much to tell in the Lincoln Assassination..so many side stories and different angles that are breezed over in THE CONSPIRATOR. Of course, there just is too much to tell in one movie. There is Booth's escape and the manhunt, the amazing journey of John Surrat to the Vatican and so much more. Here we have basically one aspect of the whole story and that is the trial of Mary Surrat.

I also know he wanted to be authentic, hence the beards, but it would have been nice to have said, they all wore beards back then, and to have made it more 2011-viewer-cinematic-friendly without them.
