The Conspirator, a Robert Redford film, covers the aftermath of President Lincoln's assassination. The focus of this film is the trial of the conspirators, with special treatment on Mrs. Mary Surratt.

Mary Surratt was a widow of property who had difficulty running a small farm, stage stop inn, and post office after the death of her husband. At the time of Lincoln's murder, she has leased the Surrattville properties and moved into Washington City (Washington, DC). She runs a boarding house. Mrs. Surratt had three children--two sons, Issaac and John and one daughter, Anna, who was actually a 13 year old girl at the time of Lincoln's murder.

Issaac has grown up and is out of the picture in terms of actual events and the world of this film. John is shown as a comrade and fellow plotter with John Wilkes Booth and the others. Anna is made older than John and somewhat self sufficient in this film.

The characters of Surratt's boarder and her inn manager/postmaster are closely drawn from the historic record. The boarder was miffed with Mrs. Surratt for butting into other boarders' business and attempting to usurp Mrs. Surratt's authority in her establishment. The stage stop inn manager was a drunk who stole from Mrs. Surratt. One point in the film that is obvious on reading the historical accounts is that the police fixed on Mrs. Surratt when Lewis Payne showed up one to two nights after the assassination looking for help; to that point, the police seemed satisfied that Mrs. Surratt was merely the mother of one alleged suspect, John and of no interest. The appearance at her boarding house changed all of that. The police detained both Mrs. Surratt and Anna for suspicion in President Lincoln's death.

Edwin Stanton is portrayed here more as a cutout than a fully developed character. The real life Stanton was obstinate, combative, paranoid, and rash and out to preserve Stanton as opposed to preserving the Union. Presumably, he kept Vice President Johnson from exercising his authority due to Lincoln's mortal wound. Further, do keep in mind that Stanton eventually controlled all the evidence and access to the conspirators and witnesses. Most persons seeing the film or even reading the accounts of the assassination may wonder why the President had no military guards or even a reliable police guard--He did have Major Rathbone who replaced General Grant who declined to attend Ford's Theatre with Lincoln; his valet; and Constable Parker of the Washington Metropolitan Police. Parker left his post and had drinks at a nearby bar, returned and took a seat in the dress circle, abandoning his chair by the door to the President's box because he couldn't see anything of the play. Stanton would not allow his chief telegrapher, a burly Army officer to accompany Lincoln, nor was he too keen on having Grant attend the theatre either.

I think that the film works more as an overview of the trial and the manner of its conduct than for the spirit of the times. When Lincoln was shot, the North was celebrating the surrender of General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia and the tension, stress, and anxiety of the shooting war was somewhat abated. In so far as I have read about Mary Surratt, she never publicly mentioned any Southern sympathy. If anything, Surratt was ambivalent.

In real life the overreaching Stanton caught a kick in the seat of his pants, courtesy of a Senate and House delegation regarding the case of Anna Surratt. Most would be shocked to hear that the girl was being held in a cell apart from her mother and without the intervention would have been turned into a co-conspirator and tried with the rest of them.

A set of facts were glossed over: the tremendous uproar of the verdict against Mrs. Surratt with the death penalty. Numerous persons protested by telegram and some letters. One of the more prominent calls for a stay of execution came from Pope Leo XIII whose telegram was personally delivered by the Papal Legate and Nuncio to President Andrew Johnson.

The film suggests that Mrs. Surratt's co-defendants had no attorneys speaking for them at the trial. This was not true. Mr. Aiken and the other defense counsels did their best against the rules of the court martial. Made some points and kept four of the conspirators from being hanged.

The film does a good job of showing how some conspirators actually had no real participation in the assassination. For example, Ed Spangler was a stage hand who held Booth's horse. Spangler had no idea that Booth would kill President Lincoln. Next, George Atzerodt, though a conspirator, never followed up on trying to kill Vice President Johnson. Instead, he had drinks in the hotel bar and left for his brother's home. He was not well off, had no horse, and walked the distance. He probably should have gotten a jail sentence rather than the hangman's rope.

Mary Surratt's crime was "having the nest that contained the assassins." I do know that Surratt was never in the same room when the conspirators discussed their plans, nor was the boarder in much proximity--he was pretty much ignored by Booth and company.

As for John Surratt, Booth's friend and young prodigy, he was not present for the assassination because he had traveled to Canada probably on a mission for the Confederate Secret Service. Eventually, he served in the papal army under an assumed name and finally returned to the United States about 7 - 12 years after the assassination. He was not convicted on the same evidence as the four hanged conspirators which included his mother.

As a starting place for the events immediately prior to, during, and after the assassination, The Conspirator does a merely satisfactory job. I did not like the license taken with Anna Surratt. The real life Anna was a child and in great peril until the intervention by the Senate-House delegation. More should have been presented on Edwin Stanton's usurpation of executive authority; control, manipulation, and tampering with evidence and witnesses and his subversion of due process and his confrontation with President Johnson that caused Johnson to fire Stanton after Johnson was acquitted at his impeachment trial which had been orchestrated in part by Edwin Stanton.

Robert Redford, as director, did a fine job as did the actors. If we think our justice system today is in need of an overhaul, you will be astounded at the rush to judgement in deciding the guilt by association and the fate of the conspirators involved in the assasination of President Lincoln.

The Conspirator, directed with skill by Robert Redford, is a sleek and atmospheric historical drama.  The story is meticulously researched and suspenseful throughout.  In the 145 years since the actual event, many theories have developed on the guilt or innocence of Mary Surratt, the boardinghouse owner whose son John was almost certainly part of the plot to assassinate Abraham Lincoln, his Vice President Andrew Johnson and his Secretary of State William H. Seward.

Many historians now agree that Mary Seward was probably part of the conspiracy.  Although she may not have taken part in the actual planning, she almost certainly knew and approved of John Wilkes Booth's plot against the government and, had she not approved, she probably would have been able to stop it.  The focus of this film is neither her innocence or guilt, but rather her lack of a fair trial, given that the Secretary of War, Edward M. Stanton, not only directed that the conspirators receive trial by a military tribunal, he was later denounced by many as tampering with witnesses during the trial.  The Supreme Court later ruled that the trial of citizens by military tribunal was unconstitutional.  Mary Surratt's son John, a courier and Confederate spy who was also probably guilty but was not apprehended until 1866, was given a trial by jury and released after his trial resulted in a hung jury.

However, the most impressive aspect of this film, aside from its predominantly historical accuracy, is the amazing amount of care that went into its visuals.  Costumes, sets, and every other physical aspect of the story are brought to life down to the smallest detail, with a look and atmosphere that makes the viewer feel they have stepped back into the middle of the 19th century.  The historic photos that were taken of the execution of the four main conspirators were the obvious source of design for the hanging scene and one has to marvel at how authentic it all looks by every account of the actual story.  The scene of the trial and execution looks precisely like the Washington arsenal where it all took place, and so do the scenes in Ford's theatre, the Surratt boardinghouse and virtually every other location used in the making of this wonderful film.

Included with the DVD is a second disc that includes a full-length documentary, with fascinating facts that I was previously unaware of, and I am a Lincoln buff.  I wish only that the film had included a little more on the attempted assassination of William H. Seward; the fact that he survived is not evident in the scene where he is attacked, although at the trial, Seward's attacker is referred to several times as the "attempted assassin".

On the whole, The Conspirator is an extremely satisfying and vividly detailed historical drama, and is sure to be enjoyed by anyone who is interested in the American Civil War or the Assassination of Abraham Lincoln.

Highly recommended.

The Lincoln assassination, right on the heels of the bloody Civil War (1861-65),
was an unprecedented emotional blow to Americans of this time.
Abraham Lincoln was the first American president to be assassinated while in office.
People were in shock, angry, wanted blood for blood!
Once the conspiracy was revealed, the powers that be were so filled with self-righteous
indignation and bloodlust, that anybody remotely affiliated with John Wilkes Booth's subversive

specialize in that particular time period have maintained in theory.

that she was not a co-conspirator in the Lincoln plot, and does everything in his power
to try to exonerate her, or at least stall things until more evidence can be gathered.

I didn't get bored at all throughout this film, and I would recommend it to anyone
who appreciates intelligent and soulful portrayals of historic events.
Mary E. Surratt became the first woman in American history to be executed by the federal government.
Many feel that if she could've been tried in a civil court, with a jury of her peers, then her
fate may have been different. But it was an all government affair, and the people wanted revenge.
Later on, after Miss Surrat is executed, her son, John Surratt, who actually was a conspirator,
and brought all of this on his mother, who then went into hiding after the assassination, who could've
saved his mother if he'd owned up to what he did, and vouched for her innocence, is apprehended,
and held for trial. But, by the time this happened, the fervor for revenge had passed, and he was set
free because no one could agree that he had any significant ties to the plot to kill Lincoln.
I wonder if he ever felt guilty for his cowardice in the face of retribution, as well as his selfish
abandonment of his mother in her hour of peril?----Hmmm, I guess we'll never know.

THE CONSPIRATOR may have had difficulty at the box office because of the controversy over the use of military tribunals that rings across the media today. But this film, based on fact but altered somewhat for cinematic purposes, deals with probably the first misuse of a military tribunal - the infamous trial of the assassinators of President Abraham Lincoln by a conspiracy of citizens, most especially the non-military affiliated Mary Surratt. James Solomon wrote the story and co-scripted the screenplay with Gregory Bernstein. The director is Robert Redford who manages to give the entire film the feeling of mid-19th century aura - visually and politically - and suggests there is little difference between the approach and consequences of that time and the current management of 'anti-government' prisoners.

The film opens with some scenes from the Civil War battlefield where we meet the severely wounded soldier Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy) attempting to save the life of his buddy Nicholas Baker (Justin Long). The film then jumps to the end of the war when the Confederate generals have surrendered to the Union generals and parties are underway. Aiken and Baker have survived and Aiken has decided to pursue law. The President is assassinated by John Wilkes Booth and in the aftermath Booth is killed but it is discovered that there was a plot to kill Lincoln as well vice president Andrew Johnson (Dennis Clark) and secretary of state (Kevin Kline). The response of the nation is terror and the suspects of the conspiracy are arrested and set for trial. The conspirators had been meeting in the boarding house of Mary Surratt (Robin Wright) so the military decides she must also be a conspirator and tried with the others 'to put this madness to an end.' The men in charge of the tribunal include Joseph Holt (Danny Huston) and David Hunter (Colm Meaney). There is one lawyer, Reverdy Johnson (Tom Wilkinson) who feels that the tribunal is not an acceptable manner in which to try a citizen and assigns the fresh new lawyer Frederick Aiken to defend Mary Surratt. At first Aiken hates his role but as time passes and he gets to know Mary Surratt he is convinced of her innocence and implores Mary (and Mary's daughter Anna - Evan Rachel Wood) to reveal the location of the true problem in their family - Mary's son John (Johnny Simmons). The story features the change of approach of Aiken and the abuse of justice at the trial and the film ends with some very poignant lessons not only about our history but also about our present.

The pacing of the film is slow at times, but the cinematography by Newton Thomas Sigel and the musical score my Mark Isham keep the film involving. James McAvoy offers a sterling performance and the rest of the cast is impressive. THE CONSPIRATOR is a healthy dip into our nation's past and makes us more alert to our nation's present. Grady Harp, August 11

THE CONSPIRATOR may have had difficulty at the box office because of the controversy over the use of military tribunals that rings across the media today. But this film, based on fact but altered somewhat for cinematic purposes, deals with probably the first misuse of a military tribunal - the infamous trial of the assassinators of President Abraham Lincoln by a conspiracy of citizens, most especially the non-military affiliated Mary Surratt.  James Solomon wrote the story and co-scripted the screenplay with Gregory Bernstein.  The director is Robert Redford who manages to give the entire film the feeling of mid-19th century aura - visually and politically - and suggests there is little difference between the approach and consequences of that time and the current management of 'anti-government' prisoners.

The film opens with some scenes from the Civil War battlefield where we meet the severely wounded soldier Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy) attempting to save the life of his buddy Nicholas Baker (Justin Long). The film then jumps to the end of the war when the Confederate generals have surrendered to the Union generals and parties are underway.  Aiken and Baker have survived and Aiken has decided to pursue law.  The President is assassinated by John Wilkes Booth and in the aftermath Booth is killed but it is discovered that there was a plot to kill Lincoln as well vice president Andrew Johnson (Dennis Clark) and secretary of state (Kevin Kline).  The response of the nation is terror and the suspects of the conspiracy are arrested and set for trial.  The conspirators had been meeting in the boarding house of Mary Surratt (Robin Wright) so the military decides she must also be a conspirator and tried with the others 'to put this madness to an end.'  The men in charge of the tribunal include Joseph Holt (Danny Huston) and David Hunter (Colm Meaney).  There is one lawyer, Reverdy Johnson (Tom Wilkinson) who feels that the tribunal is not an acceptable manner in which to try a citizen and assigns the fresh new lawyer Frederick  Aiken to defend Mary Surratt.  At first Aiken hates his role but as time passes and he gets to know Mary Surratt he is convinced of her innocence and implores Mary  (and Mary's daughter Anna - Evan Rachel Wood) to reveal the location of the true problem in their family - Mary's son John (Johnny Simmons).  The story features the change of approach of Aiken and the abuse of justice at the trial and the film ends with some very poignant lessons not only about our history but also about our present.

The pacing of the film is slow at times, but the cinematography by Newton Thomas Sigel and the musical score my Mark Isham keep the film involving.  James McAvoy offers a sterling performance and the rest of the cast is impressive.  THE CONSPIRATOR is a healthy dip into our nation's past and makes us more alert to our nation's present. Those films concerning the darker sides of the human condition which often questions our prejudicial attitudes, those attitudes we assume to be unshakable, are often the most important but not always the most popular. "The Conspirator" certainly resides in this category, a very tough and brutal episode of post-Civil War northern justice which puts into question the idea "the North" were all heroes, and "the South" were all villains. The story concerns the federal case against Mary Surratt whose only crime may have been owning the boarding house where the conspirators against Abraham Lincoln met to plan for the president's assassination only days after Lee surrendered to Grant. The trial may have been dangerously close to a kangaroo court in which a guilty verdict was preordained before the beginning of the trial as a means to restore peace. The two prejudicial attitudes the movie questions are the oft-portrayed morality of the North as opposed to the South, and that people who are put on trial must be guilty of something. Law enforcement does often operate with political ends in mind over carrying out justice, which is simply the punishment of the guilty and the freedom of the innocent.

In a sense, "the Conspirator" is about the post-Civil War legal system of the United States being "on trial". Secretary of War Stanton (played by Kevin Kline in one of his best performances) argues Surratt must be found guilty and condemned with the other conspirators as it will send a message of fear which will supposedly deter future conspirators and put a final end to all rebellion. The conspirators along with Surratt stand trial in a military tribunal, even though all are essentially civilians. However it appears there was really little or no evidence tying Surratt directly with the Lincoln assassination conspiracy. Her only crimes may have been knowing that some southerners were going to perpetrate some kind of crime, and these men were under her roof. Her other crime was she was a southern sympathizer, although based on historical evidence, the general consensus among scholars is she ultimately had nothing to do with it. Being a southern woman, the implication is the case against her is guilt by association.

Robin Wright offers a tour-de-force Academy-Award-caliber performance as Mary Surratt, a rather emotionally detached southern sympathizer, which she most probably was. Rather than playing into our escapist notions of unfair justice by portraying her as a completely sympathetic, beautiful, kind and loving character who becomes a victim of vigilante justice, the film presents her almost indifferently, as a somber and joyless prisoner. James MacAvoy plays Frederick Aiken, an attorney who previously fought for the Union side of the American Civil War, who reluctantly takes her case. Both Surratt and Aiken seem to have mutual distrust of one another when the case begins, but gradually Aiken believes a gross miscarriage of justice may be taking place. Aiken finds his footing when he begins to believe the fight is for rights guaranteed by the US Constitution and not just for Surratt.

Whether or not Surratt held onto to her southern leanings is not the point. The issue is whether or not a person should stand trial for a crime in which the evidence is largely associational and hearsay. And should the rule of law be compromised for the sake of other ends, such as for demonstrative purposes. Is the fact she owned a boarding house in which some conspirators met to perpetrate one of the most heinous of crimes in US history enough to hang her? She was accused of actively taking part in a conspiracy that led to the assassination of President Lincoln. Four others whose involvement was incidental at best, such as a Ford stage hand who had seen to Booth's horse being tethered on the fateful night, were sentenced to life in prison. John Surratt, Mary's son, may have had more knowledge of the conspiracy but remained in hiding during the trial. John Wilkes Booth who was ultimately responsible for Lincolin's death escaped the humiliation of trial and execution when he was killed by federal troops while on the run. The implication is the state department wanted a fourth conspirator, and Mary Surratt became the scape-goat for the fourth noose.

Redford was asked in an interview if he thought Mary Surratt was guilty, and his response was that she probably knew something, which is essentially my own view. However, knowing bits and pieces about a possible act in the future is not the same as being directly involved. The historical evidence is clear that she was put on trial as a fellow conspirator, not for failing to report overhearing plans for criminal behavior. She could have been charged with misprision of felony, which is essentially failing to report evidence and/or knowledge of a crime to law enforcement when she learned that some of her boarders were contemplating criminal behavior. I believe even during the 19th century, withholding evidence was not a hanging offense. But the powers-that-be decided swift and brutal justice was necessary to end all contemplations of future conspiracy, and Mary Surratt was added to the list of conspirators. I wonder what Abraham Lincoln would have thought about these proceedings, and if he would have approved of the course of some of the trials. Based on what I know of Lincoln, and I'm no scholar, I would have to conclude he would have detested how these proceedings were conducted and at least altered their conduct if he had had the power to do so.

"The Conspirator" covers an event little known to most Americans.  That is, the trial of Mary Suratt for allegedly conspiring in the assassination of Abraham Lincoln and the attempted assassinations of Andrew Johnson (Vice President) and William Seward (Secretary of Sate).  All are to some degree aware of Lincoln's demise.  Few would have any knowledge of the broader conspiracy.

Robert Redford is to be commended for bringing this story to a wider audience. However, as with much of Redford's work, there is broader underlying theme.  In this case, it is the use of almost summary justice whereby individuals can be tried before a military commission rather than a jury of their peers.  For Mary Suratt, it was almost as if the result had been pre-determined.  The North was in a vengeful mood and nothing was going to stop Mary Suratt from being found guilty.  She was never to be allowed a fair trial.

The obvious analogy being worked here is the current events in Guantanomo Bay.  Detainees have been held for years without any real prospect of facing a fair trial.  Justice has been allowed to take a back seat to revenge.  This is a shame.  America is better than this and herein lies Redford's point.  Liberty must always trump fear.

"The Conspirator" is good without being great.  It is skillfully made and never fails to grab the viewer's attention.  If I was to find criticism, it is that Redford can sometimes try a bit too hard.  Has he allowed the Suratt story to become just a bit too concocted in the process of making a political point?  Arguably, yes.  Nonetheless, the story never fails to captivate.

Redford's heavy-handed portrayal of the US' treatment of war criminals rang pretty hollow in the theater the day we went to see this film---it was the day after the assassination of Osama Bin Laden, and even at that time, information was trickling out that the 9/11 Mastermind's whereabouts were provided via interrogation methods practiced in POW camps. Too bad for Mary Surratt---Even through the refining lens of a century and a half of events and experiences, the audience was all too aware of the "ends justify the means" scenario being played out on the international stage and couldn't really drum up much support for the woman who owned the "plot--hatching nest" for the Lincoln kidnap/assassination conspiracy. (Perhaps Redford could have argued for a change of venue for the film's release?)

Historical details and characterizations aside, the only character that came across as more than a 2-dimensional parody of the players at that time was James McAvoy, who played the role of Surratt's lawyer, Frederick Aiken. He brought depth to the role as he struggled with his involvement in the entire episode---as a Civil War veteran who loved his Commander-in-Chief, to a young lawyer devestated by the murder of his president, to a young man whose eyes are opened to the possibility that "gray areas" exist in ALL matters of life & death and that even those accused of the worst crimes deserve fair treatment at the hands of the government. His transformation from dewy-eyed legal infant to a more jaded realist caught and pummeled by the system he strove to defend was the one stand-out performance in an otherwise lackluster field of acting. Alexis Bloedl ("OMG! Rory Gilmore!") simpered her way from devoted girlfriend to socially-aware bit player with a few eye rolls and well-placed head shakes; Kevin Kline, often brilliant in other roles, couldn't get the audience past the concept that he was playing an inherently evil Secretary of War who had no  agenda other than holding, manipulating and trampling on the rights of the accused ("Let's see....What shall I do today? I know! I'll destroy the lives of as many undesireables as possible, and I'll look good while doing it!") Robin Wright as Mary Surratt, brought a quiet graciousness to the role and provided a meek counterpart to the seething deviousness of those on the government's payroll; her devotion to the protection of her children and the preservation of her family outweighed her desire for life or freedom, and this came across fairly well in spite of the blusterings of the men engaged in determining her ultimate fate.

In short---this film has wonderful historic detail in depicting the tumultuousness of a healing country in its post-Civil War era; unfortunately, it does not offer the same examination of the complexity of character of the people involved in promoting that healing.

When I went to see this movie I knew nothing about it. The trailer merely indicated a period courtroom drama starring James McAvoy. While I would hesitate to call it one of the best movies of the year, undoubtedly this movie or more precisely the story this movie relates impacted me more deeply than most do. So much so that I have bought several books on the subject to get as full an understanding of this event as possible. As an experienced director and actor Robert Redford knows how to push the audiences buttons, making socially relevant, and relatable movies. Here then a true story of a divided country just arrived at an uneasy peace after a bitter civil war, when recently reinaugurated President Lincoln is suddenly assassinated by an actor in a theater. Not only is the president assassinated, there is a simultaneous attempt to murder the Secretary of State Seward, and Vice President Johnson. As the manhunt begins for Booth, and his accomplices, suspicions turn to a young known associate John Surratt. Police go to his house, and in his absence end up arresting his mother Mary Surratt for being complicit in the crime of which he is suspected. But is she guilty of being a conspirator, or just guilty of being a mother of an alleged one, an innocent running a boarding house where these conspirators would meet? She is remanded to be tried in a military court. Frank Aiken, a young veteran of the Union Army, becomes her unwilling counsel. Her rights to a jury trial in a civilian court overruled, one can sense that the odds stacked against her. It's a desperate situation. Her guilt appears to be a foregone conlusion. She is not permitted to testify in her own defencse. Will her son return and save the day? If you're like me these are some of the questions that may run through your mind as you watch this movie. Other people arrested with her testify for the state implicating her in the conspiracy. These people are not themselves charged. An alcoholic bartender, John Lloyd, very lucky not to be charged himself firmly impicates her with extremely damning uncorroborated testimony. A boarder Louis Weichman testifies that some of the conspirators met at her house on numerous occasions. But if he knew so much how come he did not report his suspicions to the authorities in advance? Probably most shocking for me was new President Johnson, suspending a writ of habeas corpus written by a judge, on a matter of life and death, a precedent ironically set by Lincoln to be used in wartime, now used to seal the conspirators fates in peacetime. I found this interference by the executive office in a judicial proceeding to be most surprising and shocking, and difficult to believe, but it turns out to be true. I checked. For dramatic purposes, some minor but significant facts have been altered. For example, Mary Surratt had two counsel not one. In addition, there were eight people on trial not four. The four not included in the movie were given life sentences, and those surviving would ultimately be pardoned by President Johnson within four years. One life sentence to Dr Mudd, 'his name is mud,' who treated Booth's fractured leg, and another to Ned Spangler, the stage hand and stable boy asked by Booth to hold his horse, while he went into the theater. President Johnson famously said of her, "She kept the nest that hatched the egg." I highly recommend this movie. If you have further interest in this topic I recommend the books: Blood on the Moon: The Assassination of Abraham Lincoln, a tremendously lucid account of events, which ties up the loose ends, particularly what happened with John Surratt. He was tried for the same crime, in a civilian court but not on the same facts. He does explore the legal standards in defining what a conspiracy is which I found helpful, and many other things. American Brutus: John Wilkes Booth and the Lincoln Conspiracies, explores not only the conspiracy, but also the life of John Wiles Booth, giving a full background. Manhunt: The 12-Day Chase for Lincoln's Killer (P.S.), which reads like a fast paced thriler while sticking to the facts. To a somewhat lesser degree The Assassin's Accomplice: Mary Surratt and the Plot to Kill Abraham Lincoln. I have browsed through this one numerous times at the local bookstore, yet have been reluctant to buy it. For one thing, she glosses over the habeas corpus issue, giving it half a page. She does not tie up the loose end of what happened with John Surratt like Steers does. She also concludes Surratt's guilt, yet I found her reasoning somewhat suspect. Even though her book ties in with the movie, I prefer that Redford allows us to make up our own minds. Two different people watching this movie could arrive at a totally different conclusion about Mary Surratt's complicity, and I think that's the way Redford would like it, to keep the mystery alive. It kept it alive for me. I hope you enjoy this movie and I hope this review was helpful.

Many Americans are using the year 2011, the 150th anniversary of the beginning of the Civil War, as an opportunity to reflect on the meanings of this seminal event in our history. "The Conspirator", a new movie directed by Robert Redford, examines the end of the Civil War rather than the beginning. The movie is set with the assassination of Abraham Lincoln on April 14, 1865 the conspiracy which planned it, and the ensuing military trials of the conspirators. The conspirators aimed to kill Vice-president Johnson and Secretary of State Seward in addition to the President and narrowly missed these goals. When John Wilkes Booth was killed, four conspirators were brought to trial including a woman, Mary Suratt, who kept a boarding house where the conspirators, among them her son, met to plan their activities. Mary Suratt's trial and the young lawyer who defended her, a Union officer in the War named Aiken, are the focus of this movie.

Mary Suratt was not an appealing defendant in any circumstances, let alone under the fear which gripped Washington after the assassination.  She was an avowed Confederate sympathizer and did little to help her pleas of innocence. She argued essentially that keeping a boarding house is no crime and that she was unaware of what her boarders may have been doing behind closed doors in their rooms.

Young Aiken took the case at the behest of venerable United States Senator from Maryland, Reverdy Johnson.  In the movie, Aiken at first shows substantial reluctance to become involved as he believes the evidence points strongly to Mary Suratt's guilt. Most historians who have since studied the matter share Aiken's initial reaction that Mary Suratt was guilty of conspiracy as charged. But Aiken pursues the case and sees good grounds to argue Suratt's innocence of conspiracy. He defends her with force, commitment, and great personal and professional cost to himself. Aiken fulfills the lawyerly mission of advocacy and defense for those unable to speak for themselves.

The movie moves back in forth between testimony at the military hearing, the underlying events on which the testimony is based, and Aiken's efforts on behalf of Mary Suratt. In general, the story line is easy to follow. The portrayals of Aiken, Mary Suratt, and Secretary of War Stanton are good as are the depictions of Civil War era Washington, D.C. The scene in which the four conspirators are hung is particularly effective, especially in its use of the photographer Matthew Brady. Brady took a famous grizzly picture of the four conspirators hanging from their ropes which is echoed well in the movie.

The movie can be viewed on several levels.  The film offers a good portrayal of the trial of Booth's conspirators, an event which may be unfamiliar to many Americans. The movie's sympathy towards Mary Suratt does not deprive it of accuracy. "The Conspirators" also has a contemporary focus. Redford draws parallels between the denial of civil liberties and fair judical process in the period following the assassination on the one hand and events in the United States following September 11, 2001, on the other hand. Viewers of the film may work through and consider the parallels.

As a retired lawyer, the part of the movie that most interested me was young Aiken and the passion he put into Mary Suratt's defense. "The Conspirators" aptly calls attention to the nobility of the law, when well practiced. The defense of unpopular causes does not know ideological boundaries. I thought of a recent event postdating the movie in which a prestigious law firm withdrew due to pressure from the defense of a Federal statute called DOMA unpopular to some people. The distinguished lawyer assigned to the case then left the law firm so that he could continue his role of vigorous defense. It was this latter action rather than the former that met the ideals of the legal profession that Aiken followed so eloquently in his defense of Mary Suratt.

Robin Friedman

The trial of Abraham Lincoln's killers has never received all that much attention. More focus is on the assassination itself, the path of the bullet, the funeral train and the tear-filled burial in Springfield. But the trial, coming as it did at a time of national grief and paranoia, had strong echoes of our current political climate, which is undoubtedly why Robert Redford decided to film it. But Redford's fast and loose approach to the facts of the case made it clear that his focus was more on filming a parable than in depicting history.

The film starts in the middle, with Redford sketching a 15-minute synopsis of the events of the assassination night. Aside from Lincoln, 2 other high government officials were targeted by conspirators led by John Wilkes Booth. Veep Andrew Johnson's attacker got cold feet and didn't act. Secretary of State Seward's face was viciously slashed in a knife attack, but his life was saved by a metal neck brace he wore on account of a recent carriage accident. Lincoln was shot in the back of the head while watching a play. Very quickly, the residents and visitors to Mary Surratt's DC boarding house (where Booth and the other conspirators hung out) were rounded up and imprisoned in connection with the crimes.

The rest of the film revolved around the case of Mary Surratt -- finding her an attorney, the details of the trial and the execution of the condemned.

I have to admit that when I first saw the film, I was excited about the lengths that Redford had gone to show us Washington as it might have appeared in 1865, with its dirt streets, horse traffic and oil illumination. James McAvoy did a creditable job portraying the youthful defense attorney Frederick Aiken. Kevin Klein played Secretary of War Edward Stanton with steel and conviction. Robin Wright was noble and mournful as Mary Surratt. The other conspirators - Booth, Herold, Powell, Mudd and the rest -- looked very much like their photographs. The scaffold build for the execution was very much the real one. Booth's death in a Virginia barn was shown fairly accurately. The actor's at Ford's spoke the right line ("you sockdolagizing old mantrap!") at the time of the shooting. And the panic as Lincoln was carried through a throng of Washingtonians to the Peterson house was fairly convincing. And the recently-completed Capitol building (its dome was finished in 1863) reared up appropriately from an as-yet-unbuilt landscape.

But after a day or two of thinking about the film and checking out historical sources, my ardor began to dim. For whatever reason, Redford changed historical details - nboth important and unimportant to the plot. He replaced Aiken's wife with a girlfriend. He erased Aiken's partner at the defense table. His Booth did not catch his spur on the bunting in front of the President's box in Ford's theater and was chased out by a theater goer. I'm sure that historians, not to mention the Civil War buffs, will find lots to quibble with regarding uniforms and tactics.

But worse than all this is the way Redford skewed his characters. The Union generals were made to appear to be bloodthirsty buffoons or calculating knaves. The Union's witnesses were shown to be liars and drunks. Meanwhile, the Southerners were simple folk infused with love of country and honor. The echoes of "Birth of a Nation" were far too strong for this Union boy's taste. The story of the conspiracy, told in flashbacks, tended to exonerate Mary Surratt. She was never shown in the same room as Booth. Indeed there was only one scene in which Redford showed her with knowledge of the conspirators' plans. In prison, she was show as sickly, or praying with a priest, or with a rosary in her hand. Redford pretty much paints her as a poor, martyred religious mom just trying to protect her kids. The reality is far murkier. She was caught in numerous deceits. Her town of Surrattsville was a known nest of Confederate spies and couriers. The testimony of numerous witnesses spun a strong web of circumstantial evidence about her involvement in the plot.

But no matter. Redford is not interested in retelling 150-year-old historical incident, but in commenting on the prisoners at Guantanamo Bay. This is a fine and even noble impulse. But to make the parallels fit, he needs to show Mary Surratt as an innocent caught in a web of paranoia and revenge. So, history must bend -- an inexcusable wrong that rewrites history to make a political point.

Strictly from a storytelling point of view, the film was a disappointment. Aside from the stunning visuals, the narrative and acting were devoid of emotion. The actors often seemed as stiff as if they were posing for a daguerreotype. The state of high-alert in the Capitol and the loathing of the rebels during the still-hot Civil War were curiously muted. Redford insists on having Aiken repeat the courtroom clich of yelling out at some injustice or other. At the trial, the other seven or so defendants were wasted - having little else to do than to sit while Surratt's trial went on. And the most interesting part of the story - the conspiracy to kidnap and then kill Lincoln - hardly made it to the screen.

A movie that gave fresh insights to our contemporary fears about invaders and the need for justice would have been welcomed. But Redford's hack job on the events of the spring and summer of 1865 did violence and injustice to history, and failed to parallel the contemporary situation. And by so one-sidedly slandering Surratt's executioners, notably by showing Stanton as a Cheneyesque bender of the law, he may inadvertently revive ancient hatreds about the war that still simmer beneath the surface of our national discourse. The Civil War was a horrific fight that was fought once and is done. Let us not vilify the victors or ennoble the vanquished, no matter how just the cause.

This is a good historical film, and director/producer Robert Redford put a lot of care into the locales, casting, and research. One does make parallels to today's post-9/11 legal situation, with military tribunals supplanting civilian courts, and the film is slanted towards favoring the latter when a more evenhanded approach might have been better. But much of the film is moving and interesting.

I liked the film's opening, which shows Frederick Aiken (James McAvoy) wounded on a Civil War battlefield, followed by celebrations after Robert E. Lee surrendered at Appomattox. Aiken soon is defending Mary Surratt (Robin Wright), the owner of the the Washington boarding house in which the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln was planned in April, 1865. Much of the film then takes place in Surratt's jail cell and in the courtroom.

Tom Wilkinson (as Senator Reverdy Johnson of Maryland, whose patriotism is questioned), Kevin Kline (as Secretary of War Edwin M. Stanton), and Evan Rachel Wood (as Surratt's daughter) are excellent in supporting roles, and McAvoy is quite good in the lead role. I also liked Wright's often subtle, ambivalent performance, as she tries to protect her son (who conspired to at least kidnap Lincoln).

Overall, I enjoyed this thoughtful and thought-provoking film.

In the days following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, the administration saw to it that the people involved were hunted down like dogs. But in their thirst for "justice," some that were possibly innocent also became victims of the war. One of those was Mary Surratt, mother of John Surratt, one of the conspirators. The trial of Mary Surratt and five other conspirators is the subject of the courtroom drama "The Conspirator," the first film from The American Film Company. Directed by Oscar winner Robert Redford, the film features an all-star cast including Robin Wright ("The Princess Bride") as Surratt; James McAvoy ("The Chronicles of Narnia," "Wanted") as Civil War veteran and Surratt attorney Frederick Aiken; Danny Huston ("John Adams," "X-Men Origins: Wolverine") as prosecutor Joseph Holt; Tom Wilkinson ("John Adams," "The Patriot") as Reverdy Johnson; and Kevin Kline ("Silverado," "Dave") as Secretary of War Edwin Stanton.
The film begins with a well-staged recreation of the assassination of Lincoln, as well as the attempted assassinations of Vice President Johnson and Secretary of State Seward. The film then quickly goes through the chase and death of Booth, and the arrests of the other conspirators involved. But the bulk of the film is taken up by the trial of the conspirators, and it is here where the film really shines. The acting, cinematography and directing all come together perfectly in these scenes, creating a vivid portrayal of the trial, and showing how this was not really a case of finding the truth, but of finding all those on trial, including Surratt, guilty and sentenced to death.
While all the performances in the film are terrific, the best comes from Kevin Kline's portrayal of Stanton. Here, we see a man out for blood, and who doesn't care if a person is possibly innocent or not. Although those on the war tribunal wanted to be lenient on Surratt on grounds of her age and gender, Stanton "convinced" them to pronounce the death sentence on her. And when Aiken was successful in having a Writ of Habeas Corpus signed by a judge to give Surratt another trial in a civilian court, you can tell that Stanton was the one who convinced President Johnson to have it more or less vetoed. Even if you don't outright hate Stanton, you strongly despise the man, which is a great testament to the acting by Kline.
The attention to historical detail is very telling in this movie. From costume design to set decoration to military drill and uniforms, you really get a sense that the production team did their research, creating a 19th Century world vividly. While the film does have one or two inaccuracies (The Writ was given to General Winfield Scott Hancock, not to Stanton), and the film does have its slower moments, "The Conspirator" is an outstanding film that presents this little-known story from our history with terrific performances, fine storytelling, a strong sense of attention to historical accuracy, and excellent direction from Redford. If you enjoy historical films, then "The Conspirator" is one you cannot afford to miss!

The worst thing that ever happened to the South after the Civil War was the assassination of Abraham Lincoln. Far from "vindicating the South and killing a tyrant" as John Wilkes Booth and the other conspirators planned, it brought a ten year reign of hellfire down upon the South. Lincoln would doubtless have preferred "malice toward none and charity for all" but his death visited a decade of "Reconstruction" suffering upon the South, including the disenfranchisement of all who fought for the Confederacy from vindictive Republicans and Northern veterans who wanted punishment not mercy. Reconstruction poisoned race relations in the South for 100 years, but that's not a topic here. The assassination was the pivotal event that started it all.

There were a number of conspirators, John Booth, John Sarratt, etc, and one, Mary Sarratt for whom there has never been any evidence that she conspired with the others. She owned and operated a boarding house on "H" St in Washington where the other conspirators met, but had no knowledge of their plans. Nevertheless there was a witch hunt by the military and the Republicans after the assassination, who saw more such rebellions lurking under each bridge and dark shadow. The military tribunal had reached the conclusion that all would hang before the "trials" started, most deservedly, but not Mary Sarratt. Seward, one if the targets of the conspirators, who was not killed in the assassination attempts, seems particularly motivated to see her hang.

Her lawyer tried to defend her, question the "evidence", even gets a writ of habeas corpus to try her in a civilian court.

Robert Redford's movie is a tense courtroom drama, all shot authentic with available light and gaslight. Excellent acting from Robin Penn Wright as tragic Mary Sarratt, and James McAvoy as her young idealistic Northern lawyer and Yankee war veteran who nevertheless believes in her right to a fair trial.
